Award.AbstractNarration:
The drone-carried WiFi communication system aims to provide WiFi infrastructure where commercial infrastructures such as AT&T and Verizon are destroyed or not available. Examples of such situations include earthquakes, rural areas and battlefields. The drone-carried WiFi communication system can provide fast-deployable and highly-flexible long-distance WiFi link for real-time text, phone, and video transmission. Potential customers include emergency response agencies such as FEMA and fire departments. With the drone-carried WiFi system, people in the emergency zone will be able to connect to outside world for information exchange through email, twitter, facebook, etc. The rescue team can also utilize the WiFi networks for task coordination and information sharing. Comparing to other existing solutions such as telecommunication trucks, the drone-carried WiFi systems can be dispatched to the destination faster, more flexibly, and with lower cost.

This I-Corps team has completed the drone-carried WiFi alpha-prototype and successfully tested the WiFi signal transmission in the air. The key technology to enable long-range WiFi transmission is to use directional instead of omnidirectional antennae by focusing all the energy in one direction. While directional antennae increase the transmission range, they require the transmitter to always face the receiver. To achieve this, the team has developed a heading control to automatically align the headings of the two antennae, despite the high mobility of drones. In this project, the team aims to transfer the demonstrable drone-carried on-demand information infrastructure to the market place. The success of this project will lead to a new start-up on the design, development and commercialization of communication infrastructures for drone networks.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this I-Corps project is to transfer the drone-carried Wi-Fi communication system to the market place. The drone-carried WiFi communication system can provide WiFi infrastructure where commercial infrastructures are destroyed or not available. Examples of such situations include disasters, public events, and activities in rural and Mountainair areas. The drone-carried WiFi communication system can provide fast-deployable and highly-flexible long-distance WiFi link for rich data types such as real-time text, phone, and video. The key technology to enable long-range WiFi transmission is to use directional instead of omnidirectional antennae by focusing all the energy in one direction. While directional antennae increase the transmission range, they require the transmitter to always face the receiver. To achieve this, the team has developed a heading control to automatically align the headings of the two antennae, despite the high mobility of drones.

During the project span, the team participated two intense I-Corp onsite seminars. During the seminars and throughout the project, we have reached out to a great range of potential customers in commercial drone applications, emergency teams, and outdoor hobbyists, and drone operators. Through the many interviews that we conducted with these potential customers, we identified emergency agencies (such as FEMA and fire departments) as the top customers for our technology. With the drone-carried WiFi system, people in the emergency zone will be able to connect to outside world for information exchange through email, twitter, facebook, etc. The rescue team can also utilize the WiFi networks for task coordination and information sharing.  Existing emergency communication solutions, such as cell-on-wheels, helicopters, and amateur radios are not effective. For instance, cell-on-wheels are constrained by terrain, amateur radios cannot support rich datatypes, and helicopters are associated with heavy costs, cannot operate at night, and are not safe considering the requirement of human pilot on board. Our technology transforms the on-demand emergency communication operations with more flexibility and lower-cost.

The main outcomes of this project include two submitted patents on related technologies, the start-up company named Aeriear Technologies inc, and one international conference paper (peer reviewed), two journal papers, and a studen thesis.

Other than the main outcomes, the team also participated in many invited/public demonstration events and invited talks for dissemination and also to collect feedback during the project span. The public demonstration events that we have participated during the project span include:

  • Invited demonstration at 2015 Defense Innovation Challenge
  • Invited talk at Beijing University of Chemical Technology in November 2015
  • Invited talk at University of Texas Arlington, November 2015
  • Invited demonstration at UNT Board of Regents Meeting, November 2015
  • Invited demonstration and poster at NSF CPS PI Meeting, November 2015
  • Invited demonstration at Hewlett-Packard (HP) “Bring Your Children to Work Day”, August 2015
  • Invited workshop discussion by the British Embassy to participate in the workshop UK-US Next-generation Air Traffic Control Systems Opportunities for Improved Research Collaboration, June 2015

  • Invited workshop discussion by the Netherland Embassy to participate in the workshop Global Smart City & Community Coalition: building a global partnership to accelerate collaboration and smart city deployments, June 2015.
